g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Proxy (=Surrogate/placeholder) A placeholder for another obje...
g.text: Proxy (=Surrogate/placeholder)A placeholder for another object to control access to it

g.title: Rectangle.119
g.desc: Virtual Proxy Create an ‘expensive’ object on demand (= lazy ...
g.text: Virtual ProxyCreate an ‘expensive’ object on demand (= lazy initialization)

g.title: Folded Corner.138
g.desc: A variant of the Proxy design pattern is the Virtual Proxy. A...

g.text: A variant of the Proxy design pattern is the Virtual Proxy. A common scenario is a client that does not require the ‘real’ object immediately, but maybe a subset of it. E.g. an e-mail service. An e-mail service does not load the content of all e-mails directly, but maybe only their date and sender. The client only requires the real object when the e-mail is opened. A Virtual Proxy can serve this on-demand need of the real subject. The Virtual Proxy encapsulates the real subject and ‘promotes’ itself via the same interface. It will be capable to fulfill simple requests where the real subject is not required. When a more ‘sophisticated’ request comes in, a request that the Proxy cannot handle, then the real subject will be created. Advantages of the Virtual Proxy are performance and memory optimization. Performance, because certain ‘expensive’ objects are not created directly. This might optimize boot-up time. The boot-up optimization is at the expense of runtime performance, because these objects still need to be created when required. However, the initialization time of the objects is more distributed and some objects might not even be needed. Memory optimization, because these ‘expensive’ objects are not directly loaded into RAM when the application starts. There might be scenarios that these objects don’t need to be created at all.

g.title: Folded Corner.205
g.desc: The Proxy design pattern compliments the Open Closed principl...

g.text: The Proxy design pattern compliments the Open Closed principle by allowing new Proxies to be introduced without changing client or subject. This enhances stability and reusability of the code base. All aspects are compared against an implementation where subject or client require change when subject constraining, optimizing or guarding logic (=Proxy) is introduced. Stability, because both client and subject remain ‘untouched’ when Proxy extension is required. The Proxy design pattern realizes this by encapsulating the subject and providing the same, identical subject interface to the client. This way the client does not ‘know’ it communicates with a Proxy or with the ‘real’ subject. Applying the Proxy design pattern reduces the risk of breaking stable, verified client or subject code. Not modifying existing production code means the test code can remain ‘untouched’. Reusability, because the client code, dependent on the subject interface, can be reused with different kind of Proxies. This is realized by the Proxy following the same interface as the subject.

g.title: Rectangle.208
g.desc: Remote Proxy Provide a placeholder for an object in a differe...
g.text: Remote ProxyProvide a placeholder for an object in a different address space

g.title: Rectangle.210
g.desc: Protection Proxy Control access to an object
g.text: Protection ProxyControl access to an object

g.title: Folded Corner.212
g.desc: A variant of the Proxy design pattern is the Remote Proxy. A ...

g.text: A variant of the Proxy design pattern is the Remote Proxy. A common scenario is a client that requires access to an object in a different address space. E.g. Client-Server interaction in a network. A Remote Proxy can facilitate the networking (network calls and connection maintenance) and provide the same interface as the remote object. The client is offloaded from the networking responsibility and will not notice it interacts with a object in another address space. A common networking sequence might be: client interacts with a client Proxy, Proxy encodes the interaction into networking calls, server Proxy decodes the network calls and remote object gets called. The Proxy serves as a stand-in for the real object located in a different address space.

g.title: Folded Corner.216
g.desc: A variant of the Proxy design pattern is the Protection Proxy...

g.text: A variant of the Proxy design pattern is the Protection Proxy. A common Use Case is that the accessibility level of an object should be dependent on the authorization of the client. I.e. different clients have different read/write access to the respective object. A Protection Proxy can facilitate this behavior by wrapping the original object and constraining the accessibility to it. Via this approach the ‘original’ object does not require change and is not ‘obscured’ with constraining functionalities. Different Protection Proxies can provide different levels of restriction. For example, multiple clients can have access to a shared drive, but read/write access is dependent on the user level. A Proxy limits users to only read or read and write. Another example; an internet cafe provides access to the internet via a https Proxy. Internet clients cannot visit gabling websites, because the https Proxy denies these web requests.

g.title: Rectangle.221
g.desc: Smart Proxy (reference) Provide memory management and thread ...
g.text: Smart Proxy (reference)Provide memory management and thread safety

g.title: Folded Corner.226
g.desc: The Proxy pattern compliments the Single Responsibility princ...

g.text: The Proxy pattern compliments the Single Responsibility principle by extracting placeholder logic from client and subject.This enhances the testability, reusability, readability and stability of the code. All aspects are compared against an implementation where client or subject is responsible for constraining, optimizing or guarding existing subject logic. Testability, because placeholder logic (=Proxy) is extracted from client and subject code. This ensures shrinkage of the client, subject and placeholder problem window. Shrinkage of the problem window results in isolated testing. Isolated testing enables bringing code faster under test and finding bugs earlier. Reusability, because different clients can reuse the Proxy logic without being dependent on another client or subject directly. The Proxy logic might be encapsulated in case a client or subject has this responsibility. This may result in partial duplication of the Proxy logic in case other clients require it as well. The Proxy pattern reduces the chance of duplication and clients being dependent on functionality they do not use (=ISP). Readability, because client and subject are not ‘obscured’ with Proxy logic. This ensures that these classes remain more ‘focused’. More ‘focused’ classes enable identifying affect of change ‘easier’. Stability, because client, subject and Proxy are distributed and do not impact each other directly when change is required. In contrast, situating the Proxy logic in subject or client code increases the risk of breaking code unrelated to change.

g.title: Folded Corner.196
g.desc: The Proxy design pattern might violate the Interface Segregat...

g.text: The Proxy design pattern might violate the Interface Segregation principle. More specific, the Protection Proxy, which is one of the applications of the Proxy design pattern. The Protection Proxy might prevent calls to the subject when the user is not authorized. The Proxy might ‘fulfill’ this call with an empty function or by throwing an unauthorized exception. This means the Proxy is dependent on an interface function it does not need/use. This violation of the ISP can result in additional maintenance and added complexity. The Proxy client might require exception handling and the Proxy requires change when the ‘uninterested’ function signature changes.

g.title: Folded Corner.235
g.desc: A variant of the Proxy design pattern is the Smart Proxy (i.e...

g.text: A variant of the Proxy design pattern is the Smart Proxy (i.e. Smart reference). A common scenario is a client that requires safety in memory management and/or multi threading environments. Memory management is often difficult in unmanaged, native languages like C++, where no garbage collection is in place. A common problem in native languages is ‘who should and when should an object be destroyed’. A concept that has now been part of the standard C++ language, called the Smart Pointer, is an implementation of the Smart Proxy used for memory management. The Smart Pointer wraps the real subject, supports its original interface and keeps additionally track of the reference count (initiated by copies). In case an copy is destroyed, the reference count is decreased. A Smart Pointer without references destroys the encapsulated subject. The Smart Proxy offloads and guarantees safety in memory management, but adds additional performance overhead and memory consumption. Another difficult aspect of software engineering is multi-threading environments. A common ‘challenge’ to overcome in a multi-threaded environment is race conditions. Thread synchronization (e.g. mutex, lock) is used to prevent race conditions. This synchronization mechanism can be facilitated via a Smart Proxy, which wraps the real subject, supports its original interface and provides a thread-safe shell. The benefit of using the Proxy is that the system can be extended, to support thread safety, without changing the original object. In this case, the Proxy is a constraining substitute for the respective subject.

g.title: Folded Corner.239
g.desc: The Proxy design pattern entails both the negative and positi...

g.text: The Proxy design pattern entails both the negative and positive side of the Open Closed principle. The pattern introduces an additional form of indirection between client and subject to comply to: ‘extension without change’. This additional form of indirect has negative impact on the navigability and debuggability of the code. It might be a more ‘suitable’ solution to change client and or subject to fulfill the Proxy responsibility and mitigate these negative side affects. This of course dependents on factors like: - the impact of change on production and test code - the reusability of the Proxy across other clients.
